docs.lead_paragraph: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it had received a subpoena from the United States attorney in Boston over pricing and marketing of drugs covered by Medicare and Medicaid. Last month, Bristol-Myers said that it started an internal review of its sales and marketing practices to make sure that they did not violate laws.

headline.main: Bristol-Myers Says It Has Been Subpoenaed

docs.abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co says it has been subpoenaed by US attorney in Boston regarding pricing of its drugs which are covered by Medicare and Medicaid; Federal prosecutors have recently begun targeting drug companies which sell drugs to government health insurance companies at excessive prices (M)
docs.snippet: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it had received a subpoena from the United States attorney in Boston over pricing and marketing of drugs covered by Medicare and Medicaid.     Last month, Bristol-Myers said that it started an...

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been a wonderful business for insurers: tens of million of dollars in premiums collected over 30 years, and not a single claim paid. So why, suddenly, do the insurers want no part of it?

headline.main: To Insurers, a Long, Free Ride Is Looking Risky

docs.abstract: Travelers Property Casualty Corporation, American International Group and Radian Asset Assurance will stop writing insurance policies for American brokerage houses; three companies are only insurers currently to offer such policies, which insure investors in event of brokerage declaring bankruptcy; have yet to pay single claim but are exiting business in wake of spate of recent corporate bankruptcies (M)
docs.snippet: It has been a wonderful business for insurers: tens of million of dollars in premiums collected over 30 years, and not a single claim paid.     So why, suddenly, do the insurers want no part of it?

docs.lead_paragraph: After more than a week of intense negotiations with the assistance of a top federal mediator, Verizon and its two main unions said yesterday that they would take a break from contract discussions until Tuesday. When the talks resume, the two sides plan to meet at two regional bargaining sites, and will not -- for the time being -- continue to negotiate in Washington with the direct assistance of the mediator, Peter Hurtgen, the director of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service.

headline.main: After a Break, Verizon Talks To Split in Two

docs.abstract: Verizon announces break in negotiations with Communications Workers of America and International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers; talks to resume Aug 12 at two separate locations; parties remain at odds over health care and job security provisions of workers' contracts (M)
docs.snippet: After more than a week of intense negotiations with the assistance of a top federal mediator, Verizon and its two main unions said yesterday that they would take a break from contract discussions until Tuesday.    When the talks resume, the two sides...

docs.lead_paragraph: In an atmosphere that hovered between carnival and chaos, Democratic leaders here today quarreled over how best to beat back the drive to recall Gov. Gray Davis. Some Democrats, embodying the contortions their party is going through, said they were prepared to keep fighting the recall while still endorsing a Democrat to replace Mr. Davis.

headline.main: Democrats Add To Chaos in Bid To Foil Recall

docs.abstract: Democratic leaders quarrel over how best to beat back drive to recall California Gov Gray Davis; some favor continuing fight, while others want to endorse Democrat to replace Davis; his aides, joined by some state and national leaders, insist party should focus on persuading voters to reject recall; 33 members of state's Democratic Congressional delegation, led by Nancy Pelosi, House minority leader, reportedly favor opposing ouster while endorsing Lt Gov Cruz M Bustamante to replace Davis; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite Republican threats that passing a contentious bill offering union concessions and forcing the governor to rehire laid-off state employees could shatter a fragile budget deal reached only last week, Democrats in the state legislature did just that today. In marathon sessions that lasted through Thursday night and into the morning today, the House passed the bill and, later in the day, Democrats in the Senate did the same.

headline.main: In Hartford, Tussle Over Bill Adds to Budget Uncertainty

docs.abstract: Democrats in Connecticut Legislature pass bill that will force Governor John G Rowland to rehire laid-off state employees; he vetoes bill; Republicans fear that what they see as undermining and sidestepping by Democrats will jeopardize completion of state budget (M)
docs.snippet: Despite Republican threats that passing a contentious bill offering union concessions and forcing the governor to rehire laid-off state employees could shatter a fragile budget deal reached only last week, Democrats in the state legislature did just...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A2-5 United States Resists Calls For Bigger Liberia Force Pentagon officials said they were resisting any significant expansion of the small number of American troops in Liberia as its president, Charles Taylor, moved closer to leaving the country. The United Nations and allies have been pressuring the Bush administration to send more troops. A1
